Award.AwardTitle: TUES Type I: Eye Trackers for Behavioral Science at Macalester and Augsburg Colleges

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The addition of eye trackers into laboratories at two institutions introduces this type of instrumentation into a broad range of psychology courses, class-associated laboratory sections, and faculty research. The project exposes a wide range of undergraduate students and faculty to state-of-the-art eye movement research techniques in five areas of psychology, linguistics, biological neuroscience, and computer science. Recent developments in video-based eye trackers are revolutionizing the ability of researchers to precisely determine where a participant is looking as a means to investigate aspects of human cognitive processing. As eye tracking technology continues to become more powerful, portable, and affordable, it has become a standard instrument for psychological science. The collaboration between Macalester College and Augsburg College reaches a diverse student population and provides another tool in the methodological arsenals available to faculty to integrate eye movement research techniques into on-going courses and laboratories. Through faculty enhancement activities, the project encourages interdisciplinary research among colleagues at other neighboring institutions along with introducing the public to eye movement science through museum-based outreach activities. As eye tracking research becomes more common in behavioral science, students and faculty mastering the methodology become more informed consumers and producers of eye movement research and educational activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A grant from the NSF (TUES program) allowed the recipients to establish eye tracking labs at Macalester College and Augsburg College. This collaborative project was initiated to expose a wide range of students at 4-year liberal arts colleges to eye movement research, to enhance the development of faculty, and to create a model for how such teaching and research labs could be created at other institutions.

The labs proved to be both effective and productive. In a four-year period, more than 1000 student participants and 40 student researchers have been engaged in lab activities. More than 20 students (and their faculty mentors) have presented their research at local, regional and/or national psychology conferences. Lab members also had the opportunity to engage community members by preparing and administering a recurring exhibit on eye tracking research at the Science Museum of Minnesota

Faculty participation in lab activities has also been robust. To date, nine faculty members across four different departments and four institutions have utilized the trackers in their research. More broadly, faculty, staff and students at the host institutions had numerous opportunities to learn about eye tracking in general and the specific activities of the lab through several workshops and information sessions that were administered by the principle investigators. The principle investigators also delivered multiple presentations on lab activities to attendees at the National Institute on the Teaching of Psychology.

Believing that this project could serve as a model for educators wishing to establish collaborative teaching and research labs, efforts were made to broadly disseminate the products generated in the labs. In addition to the numerous workshops and conference presentations, information is also disseminated through a lab website (www.macalester.edu/ilab). Instructive products available on the website include: training videos on how to program and operate eye trackers, plug and play experiments/demonstrations, readings and assignments related to the experiments/demonstrations, and a library of eye tracking articles and resources.
